segment.source: Use the inclinometer
segment.target: Use the inclinometer

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Learn how to use the inclinometer to determine pitch, roll, and yaw.
segment.target: Learn how to use the inclinometer to determine pitch, roll, and yaw.

segment.source: Some 3-D games require an inclinometer as an input device.
segment.target: Some 3-D games require an inclinometer as an input device.

segment.source: One common example is the flight simulator, which maps the three axes of the inclinometer (X, Y, and Z) to the elevator, aileron, and rudder inputs of the aircraft.
segment.target: One common example is the flight simulator, which maps the three axes of the inclinometer (X, Y, and Z) to the elevator, aileron, and rudder inputs of the aircraft.

segment.source: ## Prerequisites
segment.target: ## Prerequisites

segment.source: You should be familiar with Extensible Application Markup Language (XAML), Microsoft Visual C\#, and events.
segment.target: You should be familiar with Extensible Application Markup Language (XAML), Microsoft Visual C\#, and events.

segment.source: The device or emulator that you're using must support a inclinometer.
segment.target: The device or emulator that you're using must support a inclinometer.

segment.source: ## Create a simple inclinometer app
segment.target: ## Create a simple inclinometer app

segment.source: This section is divided into two subsections.
segment.target: This section is divided into two subsections.

segment.source: The first subsection will take you through the steps necessary to create a simple inclinometer application from scratch.
segment.target: The first subsection will take you through the steps necessary to create a simple inclinometer application from scratch.

segment.source: The following subsection explains the app you have just created.
segment.target: The following subsection explains the app you have just created.

segment.source: Instructions
segment.target: Instructions

segment.source: Create a new project, choosing a Blank App (Universal Windows) from the Visual C\# project templates.
segment.target: Create a new project, choosing a Blank App (Universal Windows) from the Visual C\# project templates.

segment.source: Open your project's MainPage.xaml.cs file and replace the existing code with the following.
segment.target: Open your project's MainPage.xaml.cs file and replace the existing code with the following.

segment.source: You'll need to rename the namespace in the previous snippet with the name you gave your project.
segment.target: You'll need to rename the namespace in the previous snippet with the name you gave your project.

segment.source: For example, if you created a project named InclinometerCS, you'd replace namespace App1 with namespace InclinometerCS.
segment.target: For example, if you created a project named InclinometerCS, you'd replace namespace App1 with namespace InclinometerCS.

segment.source: Open the file MainPage.xaml and replace the original contents with the following XML.
segment.target: Open the file MainPage.xaml and replace the original contents with the following XML.

segment.source: You'll need to replace the first part of the class name in the previous snippet with the namespace of your app.
segment.target: You'll need to replace the first part of the class name in the previous snippet with the namespace of your app.

segment.source: For example, if you created a project named InclinometerCS, you'd replace x:Class="App1.MainPage" with x:Class="InclinometerCS.MainPage".
segment.target: For example, if you created a project named InclinometerCS, you'd replace x:Class="App1.MainPage" with x:Class="InclinometerCS.MainPage".

segment.source: You should also replace xmlns:local="using:App1" with xmlns:local="using:InclinometerCS".
segment.target: You should also replace xmlns:local="using:App1" with xmlns:local="using:InclinometerCS".

segment.source: Press F5 or select Debug > Start Debugging to build, deploy, and run the app.
segment.target: Press F5 or select Debug > Start Debugging to build, deploy, and run the app.

segment.source: Once the app is running, you can change the inclinometer values by moving the device or using the emulator tools.
segment.target: Once the app is running, you can change the inclinometer values by moving the device or using the emulator tools.

segment.source: Stop the app by returning to Visual Studio and pressing Shift+F5 or select Debug > Stop Debugging to stop the app.
segment.target: Stop the app by returning to Visual Studio and pressing Shift+F5 or select Debug > Stop Debugging to stop the app.

segment.source: Explanation
segment.target: Explanation

segment.source: The previous example demonstrates how little code you'll need to write in order to integrate inclinometer input in your app.
segment.target: The previous example demonstrates how little code you'll need to write in order to integrate inclinometer input in your app.

segment.source: The app establishes a connection with the default inclinometer in the MainPage method.
segment.target: The app establishes a connection with the default inclinometer in the MainPage method.

segment.source: The app establishes the report interval within the MainPage method.
segment.target: The app establishes the report interval within the MainPage method.

segment.source: This code retrieves the minimum interval supported by the device and compares it to a requested interval of 16 milliseconds (which approximates a 60-Hz refresh rate).
segment.target: This code retrieves the minimum interval supported by the device and compares it to a requested interval of 16 milliseconds (which approximates a 60-Hz refresh rate).

segment.source: If the minimum supported interval is greater than the requested interval, the code sets the value to the minimum.
segment.target: If the minimum supported interval is greater than the requested interval, the code sets the value to the minimum.

segment.source: Otherwise, it sets the value to the requested interval.
segment.target: Otherwise, it sets the value to the requested interval.

segment.source: The new inclinometer data is captured in the ReadingChanged method.
segment.target: The new inclinometer data is captured in the ReadingChanged method.

segment.source: Each time the sensor driver receives new data from the sensor, it passes the values to your app using this event handler.
segment.target: Each time the sensor driver receives new data from the sensor, it passes the values to your app using this event handler.

segment.source: The app registers this event handler on the following line.
segment.target: The app registers this event handler on the following line.

segment.source: These new values are written to the TextBlocks found in the project's XAML.
segment.target: These new values are written to the TextBlocks found in the project's XAML.
